DataElement.preferredName: Normal Rectal Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue Biopsy Number
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The number of normal rectal mucosal biopsies taken.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Normal Rectal Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue Biopsy
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information pertaining to the removal and pathologic examination of lymphoid tissue specimens located beneath the mucosal epithelia of those mucosal surfaces that have contact with the external environment, such as the rectum.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm. (NCI):Rectal; of, or pertaining to, the rectum.

Concepts.definition: Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm.
Of or pertaining to the rectum.

Property.preferredDefinition: Lymphoid tissue located beneath the mucosal epithelia of those mucosal surfaces that have contact with the external environment, such as the respiratory, digestive, and urinary systems. MALT consists of a collection of predominantly small lymphocytes, fewer larger, transformed lymphocytes, and plasma cells. It protects the body from pathogens that enter via the mucosa. MALT gives rise to a distinctive type of B-cell lymphoma that usually follows an indolent clinical course.:Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.

Concepts.definition: Lymphoid tissue located beneath the mucosal epithelia of those mucosal surfaces that have contact with the external environment, such as the respiratory, digestive, and urinary systems. MALT consists of a collection of predominantly small lymphocytes, fewer larger, transformed lymphocytes, and plasma cells. It protects the body from pathogens that enter via the mucosa. MALT gives rise to a distinctive type of B-cell lymphoma that usually follows an indolent clinical course.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Number; a concept of quantity derived from zero and units; a numeral or string of numerals that is used for identification.

Concepts.definition: A numeral or string of numerals expressing value, quantity, or identification.
